<!--https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-adjectives-and-adverbs/adjectives-forms#forming-adjectives-from-other-words-->
<h1>Adjectives: forms</h1>            <div class="fcdo-s20">from <a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/english-grammar-today/" class="a--rev">English Grammar Today</a></div>
</div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>Unlike in many other languages, adjectives in English do not change (agree) with the noun that they modify:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">All new <b class="b">foreign students</b> are welcome to join the clubs and societies.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">All new foreigns students</s> …</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Every room was painted in <b class="b">different colours</b>.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p">Not: … <s class="s">in differents colours</s>.</p></blockquote><div class="section_anchor" id="identifying-adjectives"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Identifying adjectives</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>There is no general rule for making adjectives. We know they are adjectives usually by what they do (their function) in a sentence. However, some word endings (suffixes) are typical of adjectives.</p><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">suffix</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">examples</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">-able</i>, <i class="i">-ible</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">comfortable, readable, incredible, invisible</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">-al</i>, <i class="i">-ial</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">comical, normal, musical, industrial, presidential</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">-ful</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">beautiful, harmful, peaceful, wonderful</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">-ic</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">classic, economic, heroic, romantic</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">-ical</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">aeronautical, alphabetical, political</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">-ish</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">British, childish, Irish, foolish</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">-<i class="i">ive</i>, -<i class="i">ative</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">active, alternative, creative, talkative</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">-<i class="i">less</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">endless, motionless, priceless, timeless</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">-<i class="i">eous</i>, -<i class="i">ious</i>, -<i class="i">ous</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">spontaneous, hideous, ambitious, anxious, dangerous, famous</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">-y</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">angry, busy, wealthy, windy</i></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Warning: </span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>Adjectives ending in <i class="i">-ic</i> and <i class="i">-ical</i> often have different meanings:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The <b class="b">economic</b> policy of this government has failed.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">A diesel car is usually more <b class="b">economical</b> than a petrol one.</i></p></blockquote></div></div><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/adjectives">Adjectives </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/classic-or-classical"><i class="i">Classic</i> or <i class="i">classical</i>? </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/economic-or-economical"><i class="i">Economic</i> or <i class="i">economical</i>? </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/historic-or-historical"><i class="i">Historic</i> or <i class="i">historical</i>? </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="forming-adjectives-from-other-words"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Forming adjectives from other words</h2></div><div class="content"><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Suffixes</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>Some adjectives are made from nouns and verbs by adding suffixes.<span class="target"/></p><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">noun</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">adjective</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">hero</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">hero</i><b class="b"><i class="i">ic</i></b></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">wind</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">wind</i><b class="b"><i class="i">y</i></b></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">child</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">child</i><b class="b"><i class="i">ish</i></b></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">beauty</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">beauti</i><b class="b"><i class="i">ful</i></b></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">verb</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">adjective</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">read</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">read</i><b class="b"><i class="i">able</i></b></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">talk</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">talkat</i><b class="b"><i class="i">ive</i></b></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">use</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">use</i><b class="b"><i class="i">ful</i></b></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">like</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">like</i><b class="b"><i class="i">able</i></b></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I hate <b class="b">windy</b> days.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">San Francisco is a very <b class="b">hilly</b> place.</i></p></blockquote><p class="p">Some words ending in <i class="i">-ly</i> can be both adjectives and adverbs. These include <i class="i">daily</i>, <i class="i">early</i>, <i class="i">monthly</i>, <i class="i">weekly</i>, <i class="i">nightly</i>, <i class="i">yearly</i>:</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Adjective: She gets a <b class="b">weekly</b> payment from her parents.</i> (She gets money every week.)</p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Adverb: I pay my rent <b class="b">weekly</b>.</i> (I pay my rent every week.)</p></blockquote><p class="p">Some words ending in -<i class="i">ly</i> are only adjectives and not adverbs. These include: <i class="i">costly</i>, <i class="i">cowardly</i>, <i class="i">deadly</i>, <i class="i">friendly</i>, <i class="i">likely</i>, <i class="i">lonely</i>, <i class="i">lovely</i>, <i class="i">oily</i>, <i class="i">orderly</i>, <i class="i">scholarly</i>, <i class="i">silly</i>, <i class="i">smelly</i>, <i class="i">timely</i>, <i class="i">ugly</i>, <i class="i">woolly</i>.</p><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We enjoyed the trip to America but it was a <b class="b">costly</b> holiday.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i"><b class="b">Oily</b> fish is very healthy because it contains omega 3.</i></p></blockquote><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-formation">Word formation </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/adverbs">Adverbs </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/prefixes">Prefixes </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/suffixes">Suffixes </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div>      <div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title">Prefixes</h3></div><div class="content"><p class="p">Prefixes such as <i class="i">un-, in-, im-</i>, <i class="i">il-</i> and <i class="i">ir-</i> change the meaning of adjectives. <span class="target"/>Adding these prefixes makes the meaning negative:</p><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">un-</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">in-</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">ir-<span class="target"/></p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">fair – unfair</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">active – inactive</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">responsible – irresponsible</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">happy – unhappy</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">appropriate – inappropriate</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">regular – irregular</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">sure – unsure</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">complete – incomplete</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">reducible – irreducible</i></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">im-</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">il-</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">balance – imbalance</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">legal – illegal</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">polite – impolite</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">legible – illegible</i></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">possible – impossible</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">logical – illogical</i></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/prefixes">Prefixes </a> </p></li><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/suffixes">Suffixes </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="adjectives-comparative-and-superlative"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Adjectives: comparative and superlative</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>Many one-syllable adjectives have endings to show the comparative and superlative.</p><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">base form</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">comparative</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">superlative</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">fine</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">fin</i><b class="b"><i class="i">er</i></b></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">fin</i><b class="b"><i class="i">est</i></b></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">young</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">young</i><b class="b"><i class="i">er</i></b></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">young</i><b class="b"><i class="i">est</i></b></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">small</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">small</i><b class="b"><i class="i">er</i></b></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">small</i><b class="b"><i class="i">est</i></b></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><p class="p">Some two-syllable adjectives which end in an unstressed syllable also have these endings.</p><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">base form</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">comparative</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">superlative</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">easy</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">eas</i><b class="b"><i class="i">ier</i></b></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">eas</i><b class="b"><i class="i">iest</i></b></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">funny</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">funn</i><b class="b"><i class="i">ier</i></b></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">funn</i><b class="b"><i class="i">iest</i></b></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">gentle</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">gentl</i><b class="b"><i class="i">er</i></b></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">gentl</i><b class="b"><i class="i">est</i></b></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><p class="p">However, we do not use these endings with two-syllable adjectives ending in a stressed syllable nor with longer adjectives with more than two syllables. The comparatives and superlatives of these adjectives are formed using <i class="i">more</i> and <i class="i">most</i>.<span class="target"/></p><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">base form</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">comparative</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">superlative</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">complete</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><b class="b"><i class="i">more</i></b> <i class="i">complete</i> Not: <s class="s">completer</s></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><b class="b"><i class="i">most</i></b> <i class="i">complete</i> Not: <s class="s">completest</s></p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><i class="i">interesting</i></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><b class="b"><i class="i">more</i></b> <i class="i">interesting</i></p><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">interestinger</s></p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><b class="b"><i class="i">most</i></b> <i class="i">interesting</i></p><p class="p">Not: <s class="s">interestingest</s></p></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="nav"><p class="p">See also: </p><ul class="ul"><li class="li"><p class="p"> <a class="Ref" href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/comparison-adjectives-bigger-biggest-more-interesting#comparison-adjectives-bigger-biggest-more-interesting__1">Comparative and superlative adjectives </a> </p></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="section_anchor" id="adjectives-with-ing-and-ed-interesting-interested"> </div><div class="section"><div class="header"><h2 class="title">Adjectives: with -<i class="i">ing</i> and -<i class="i">ed</i> (<i class="i">interesting</i>, <i class="i">interested</i>)</h2></div><div class="content"><p class="p"><span class="target"/>We use the -<i class="i">ing</i> and -<i class="i">ed</i> forms of regular and irregular verbs as adjectives:<span class="target"/></p><div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title"><i class="i">-ing forms</i></h3></div><div class="content"><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">verb</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">example</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">annoy</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">My brother is five and he’s so <b class="b">annoying</b>.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">amaze</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The Grand Canyon is an <b class="b">amazing</b> place.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">boil</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Be careful! That’s <b class="b">boiling</b> water!</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">excite</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">This film is not very <b class="b">exciting</b>, is it?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div></div>
<div id='ad_contentslot_1' class='am-default contentslot'>
</div>
<div class="section"><div class="header"><h3 class="title"><i class="i">-ed forms</i></h3></div><div class="content"><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><thead class="thead"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">verb</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p">example</p></td></tr></thead><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">bore</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Why do teenagers always look <b class="b">bored</b>?</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">pack</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">James Bond movies are always <b class="b">action</b>-<b class="b">packed</b>.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">smoke</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">Not everyone likes <b class="b">smoked</b> salmon.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">make</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">My dress is <b class="b">hand-made</b>. I really like it.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">teach</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">My Master’s degree was a <b class="b">taught</b> course.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p">excite</p></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I feel <b class="b">excited</b> about my new job.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><p class="p">Adjectives with -<i class="i">ing</i> and -<i class="i">ed</i> endings have different meanings.</p><div class="panel"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title"/></div><div class="panel-body"><table class="table"><span class="colgroup"><col class="col"/><col class="col"/></span><tbody class="tbody"><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><p class="p"><b class="b">-</b><b class="b"><i class="i">ing</i></b> <b class="b">adjectives</b></p><p class="p">-<i class="i">ing</i> adjectives describe the effect</p></td><td class="td"><p class="p"><b class="b"><i class="i">-ed</i></b> <b class="b">adjectives</b></p><p class="p"><i class="i">-ed</i> adjectives describe how a person feels</p></td></tr><tr class="tr"><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">The meeting was very <b class="b">boring</b>.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">That was an <b class="b">exciting</b> game.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">It was <b class="b">shocking</b> to see what the storm had done to the house.</i></p></blockquote></td><td class="td"><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">I felt <b class="b">bored</b> at the meeting.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We were really <b class="b">excited</b> about the game.</i></p></blockquote><blockquote class="blockquote"><p class="p"><i class="i">We were <b class="b">shocked</b> to see what the storm had done to the house.</i></p></blockquote></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div><div class="panel pad-indent"><div class="panel-head"><span class="panel-title">Warning: </span></div><div class="panel-body pad-indent"><p class="p">Commonly confused pairs of adjectives ending in -<i class="i">ing</i> and -<i class="i">ed</i> are: <i class="i">interesting</i>, <i class="i">interested</i>; <i class="i">boring</i>, <i class="i">bored</i>; <i class="i">exciting</i>, <i class="i">excited</i>; <i class="i">embarrassing</i>, <i class="i">embarrassed</i>.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></article>
</div>
</div>
<div class="clrd">
<div class="mod float-xl">
<div id='ad_btmslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_b' class='am-default '>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="cdo-tpl__z cdo-tpl-main__z3 clrd">
<div class="mod mod--dark mod--style1">

<b>Table of contents</b>

<ul>
<li class="section">
<a>Adjectives and adverbs</a>
<ul>
<li class="section">
<a>about adjectives and adverbs</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-adjectives-and-adverbs/adjectives">Adjectives</a>
</li>
<li class="section current">
<a>Adjectives: forms</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-adjectives-and-adverbs/adjectives-forms#adjectives-with-ing-and-ed-interesting-interested">Adjectives: with -<i>ing</i> and -<i>ed</i> (<i>interesting</i>, <i>interested</i>)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-adjectives-and-adverbs/adjectives-forms#forming-adjectives-from-other-words">Forming adjectives from other words</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-adjectives-and-adverbs/adjectives-forms#identifying-adjectives">Identifying adjectives</a>

</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-adjectives-and-adverbs/adjectives-order">Adjectives: order</a>

</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-adjectives-and-adverbs/adverbs-and-adverb-phrases-typical-errors">Adverbs and adverb phrases: typical errors</a>

<li>

<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/adjectives">adjectives</a>
</li>

<li class="section">
<a>Easily confused words</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/above-or-over"><i>Above</i> or <i>over?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/across-over-or-through"><i>Across</i>, <i>over</i> or <i>through</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/advice-or-advise"><i>Advice</i> or <i>advise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/affect-or-effect"><i>Affect</i> or <i>effect</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-every"><i>All</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/all-or-whole"><i>All</i> or <i>whole</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/allow-permit-or-let"><i>Allow</i>, <i>permit</i> or <i>let</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/almost-or-nearly"><i>Almost</i> or <i>nearly</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alone-lonely-or-lonesome"><i>Alone</i>, <i>lonely</i>, or <i>lonesome</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/along-or-alongside"><i>Along</i> or <i>alongside</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/already-still-or-yet"><i>Already</i>, <i>still</i> or <i>yet</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/also-as-well-or-too"><i>Also</i>, <i>as well</i> or <i>too</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/alternate-ly-alternative-ly"><i>Alternate(ly)</i>, <i>alternative(ly)</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/although-or-though"><i>Although</i> or <i>though</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/altogether-or-all-together"><i>Altogether</i> or <i>all together</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/amount-of-number-of-or-quantity-of"><i>Amount of</i>, <i>number of</i> or <i>quantity of</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/any-more-or-anymore"><i>Any more</i> or <i>anymore</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/anyone-anybody-or-anything"><i>Anyone</i>, <i>anybody</i> or <i>anything</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/apart-from-or-except-for"><i>Apart from</i> or <i>except for</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arise-or-rise"><i>Arise</i> or <i>rise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/around-or-round"><i>Around</i> or <i>round</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/arouse-or-rouse"><i>Arouse</i> or <i>rouse</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-or-like"><i>As</i> or <i>like</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-because-or-since"><i>As</i>, <i>because</i> or <i>since</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-when-or-while"><i>As</i>, <i>when</i> or <i>while</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/been-or-gone"><i>Been</i> or <i>gone</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/begin-or-start"><i>Begin</i> or <i>start</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/beside-or-besides"><i>Beside</i> or <i>besides</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/between-or-among"><i>Between</i> or <i>among</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/born-or-borne"><i>Born</i> or <i>borne</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/bring-take-and-fetch"><i>Bring</i>, <i>take</i> and <i>fetch</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/can-could-or-may"><i>Can</i>, <i>could</i> or <i>may</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/classic-or-classical"><i>Classic</i> or <i>classical?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/come-or-go"><i>Come</i> or <i>go?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consider-or-regard"><i>Consider</i> or <i>regard</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/consist-comprise-or-compose"><i>Consist</i>, <i>comprise</i> or <i>compose</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/content-or-contents"><i>Content</i> or <i>contents?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/different-from-different-to-or-different-than"><i>Different from</i>, <i>different to</i> or <i>different than</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/do-or-make"><i>Do</i> or <i>make</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/down-downwards-or-downward"><i>Down, downwards or <i>downward?</i></i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/during-or-for"><i>During</i> or <i>for?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/each-or-every"><i>Each</i> or <i>every</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/east-or-eastern-north-or-northern"><i>East</i> or <i>eastern</i>; <i>north</i> or <i>northern</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/economic-or-economical"><i>Economic</i> or <i>economical</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/efficient-or-effective"><i>Efficient</i> or <i>effective</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/elder-eldest-or-older-oldest"><i>Elder</i>, <i>eldest</i> or <i>older</i>, <i>oldest</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/end-or-finish"><i>End</i> or <i>finish</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/especially-or-specially"><i>Especially</i> or <i>specially</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/every"><i>Every one</i> or <i>everyone</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/except-or-except-for"><i>Except</i> or <i>except for</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/expect-hope-or-wait"><i>Expect</i>, <i>hope</i> or <i>wait</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/experience-or-experiment"><i>Experience</i> or <i>experiment</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/fall-or-fall-down"><i>Fall</i> or <i>fall down</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/far-or-a-long-way"><i>Far</i> or <i>a long way</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/farther-farthest-or-further-furthest"><i>Farther</i>, <i>farthest</i> or <i>further</i>, <i>furthest</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/fast-quick-or-quickly"><i>Fast</i>, <i>quick</i> or <i>quickly</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/fell-or-felt"><i>Fell</i> or <i>felt</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/female-or-feminine-male-or-masculine"><i>Female</i> or <i>feminine</i>; <i>male</i> or <i>masculine</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/finally-at-last-lastly-or-in-the-end"><i>Finally</i>, <i>at last</i>, <i>lastly</i> or <i>in the end?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/first-firstly-or-at-first"><i>First</i>, <i>firstly</i> or <i>at first</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/fit-or-suit"><i>Fit</i> or <i>suit</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/following-or-the-following"><i>Following</i> or <i>the following</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/for-or-since"><i>For</i> or <i>since</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/forget-or-leave"><i>Forget</i> or <i>leave</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/full-or-filled"><i>Full</i> or <i>filled</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/fun-or-funny"><i>Fun</i> or <i>funny</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/get-or-go"><i>Get</i> or <i>go?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/grateful-or-thankful"><b tag="b"><i>Grateful</i> or <i>thankful</i>?</b></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/hear-or-listen-to"><i>Hear</i> or <i>listen (to)</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/high-or-tall"><i>High</i> or <i>tall</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/historic-or-historical"><i>Historic</i> or <i>historical</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/house-or-home"><i>House</i> or <i>home</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/how-is-or-what-is-like"><i>How is …?</i> or <i>What is … like?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/if-or-when"><i>If</i> or <i>when</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/if-or-whether"><i>If</i> or <i>whether</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/ill-or-sick"><i>Ill</i> or <i>sick</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/imply-or-infer"><i>Imply</i> or <i>infer</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/in-the-way-or-on-the-way"><i>In the way</i> or <i>on the way</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/its-or-its"><i>It’s</i> or <i>its</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/late-or-lately"><i>Late</i> or <i>lately</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/lay-or-lie"><i>Lay</i> or <i>lie</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/lend-or-borrow"><i>Lend</i> or <i>borrow</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/less-or-fewer"><i>Less</i> or <i>fewer</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/look-at-see-or-watch"><i>Look at</i>, <i>see</i> or <i>watch</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/low-or-short"><i>Low</i> or <i>short</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/man-mankind-or-people"><i>Man</i>, <i>mankind</i> or <i>people</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/maybe-or-may-be"><i>Maybe</i> or <i>may be</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/maybe-or-perhaps"><i>Maybe</i> or <i>perhaps</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/nearest-or-next"><i>Nearest</i> or <i>next</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/never-or-not-ever"><i>Never</i> or <i>not … ever?</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/nice-or-sympathetic"><i>Nice</i> or <i>sympathetic</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/no-doubt-or-without-doubt"><i>No doubt</i> or <i>without doubt</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/no-or-not"><i>No</i> or <i>not</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/nowadays-these-days-or-today"><i>Nowadays</i>, <i>these days</i> or <i>today</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/open-or-opened"><i>Open</i> or <i>opened</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/opportunity-or-possibility"><i>Opportunity</i> or <i>possibility</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/opposite-or-in-front-of"><i>Opposite</i> or <i>in front of</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/other-others-the-other-or-another"><i>Other</i>, <i>others</i>, <i>the other</i> or <i>another</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/out-or-out-of"><i>Out</i> or <i>out of</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/permit-or-permission"><i>Permit</i> or <i>permission</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/person-persons-or-people"><i>Person</i>, <i>persons</i> or <i>people</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/pick-or-pick-up"><i>Pick</i> or <i>pick up</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/play-or-game"><i>Play</i> or <i>game</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/politics-political-politician-or-policy"><i>Politics</i>, <i>political</i>, <i>politician</i> or <i>policy</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/price-or-prize"><i>Price</i> or <i>prize</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/principal-or-principle"><i>Principal</i> or <i>principle</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/quiet-or-quite"><i>Quiet</i> or <i>quite</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/raise-or-rise"><i>Raise</i> or <i>rise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/remember-or-remind"><i>Remember</i> or <i>remind</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/right-or-rightly"><i>Right</i> or <i>rightly</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/rob-or-steal"><i>Rob</i> or <i>steal</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/say-or-tell"><i>Say</i> or <i>tell</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/so-that-or-in-order-that"><i>So that</i> or <i>in order that</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/sometimes-or-sometime"><i>Sometimes</i> or <i>sometime</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/sound-or-noise"><i>Sound</i> or <i>noise</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speak-or-talk"><i>Speak</i> or <i>talk</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/such-or-so"><i>Such</i> or <i>so</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/there-their-or-theyre"><i>There</i>, <i>their</i> or <i>they’re</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/towards-or-toward"><i>Towards</i> or <i>toward</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/wait-or-wait-for"><i>Wait</i> or <i>wait for</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/wake-wake-up-or-awaken"><i>Wake</i>, <i>wake up</i> or <i>awaken</i>?</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/worth-or-worthwhile"><i>Worth</i> or <i>worthwhile</i>?</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Nouns, pronouns and determiners</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-nouns">about nouns</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/common-nouns">common nouns</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/determiners">determiners</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/noun-phrases">noun phrases</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/pronouns">pronouns</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/quantifiers">quantifiers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/question-words">question words</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/uncountable-nouns">uncountable nouns</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Prepositions and particles</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/above"><i>Above</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/after-afterwards"><i>After</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/against"><i>Against</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/among-and-amongst"><i>Among</i> and <i>amongst</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/at"><i>At</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/at-in-and-to-movement"><i>At</i>, <i>in</i> and <i>to</i> (movement)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/at-on-and-in-place"><i>At</i>, <i>on</i> and <i>in</i> (place)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/at-on-and-in-time"><i>At</i>, <i>on</i> and <i>in</i> (time)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/below"><i>Below</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/beneath"><i>Beneath</i>: meaning and use</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/beyond"><i>Beyond</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/by"><i>By</i> + <i>myself</i> etc.</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/during"><i>During</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/for"><i>For</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/for-ing"><i>For</i> + <i>-ing</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/from"><i>From</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/in-front-of"><i>In front of</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/in-spite-of-and-despite"><i>In spite of</i> and <i>despite</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/in-into"><i>In, into</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/near-and-near-to"><i>Near</i> and <i>near to</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/of"><i>Of</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/on-onto"><i>On</i>, <i>onto</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/over"><i>Over</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/prepositional-phrases">Prepositional phrases</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/prepositions">Prepositions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/to"><i>To</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/under"><i>Under</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/until"><i>Until</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/with"><i>With</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/within"><i>Within</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/without"><i>Without</i></a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Words, sentences and clauses</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-words-clauses-and-sentences">about words, clauses and sentences</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/as-and-as-expressions"><i>as</i> and <i>as</i> expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/comparing-and-contrasting">comparing and contrasting</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/conditionals-and-wishes">conditionals and wishes</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/linking-words-and-expressions">linking words and expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/questions-and-negative-sentences">questions and negative sentences</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/relative-clauses">relative clauses</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/reported-speech">reported speech</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/so-and-such"><i>so</i> and <i>such</i></a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-formation">word formation</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/word-order-and-focus">word order and focus</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Using English</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/discourse-markers">discourse markers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/emphasising-and-downtoning">emphasising and downtoning</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/functions">functions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/numbers">numbers</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/people-and-places">people and places</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/speaking">speaking</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/types-of-english-formal-informal-etc">types of English (formal, informal, etc.)</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/useful-phrases">useful phrases</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/writing">writing</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li class="section">
<a>Verbs</a>
<ul>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/about-verbs">about verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/be-and-be-expressions"><i>be</i> and <i>be</i> expressions</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/common-verbs">common verbs</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/future">future</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/infinitives-and-imperatives">infinitives and imperatives</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/modals-and-modality">modals and modality</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/passive">passive</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/past">past</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/present">present</a>
</li>
<li>
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/grammar/british-grammar/verb-patterns">verb patterns</a>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</div>
<div id='ad_houseslot_a' class='am-default '>
</div>
<div class="mod mod--dark mod--style2 oflow-hide">
<div class="pad">
<p class="h2 semi-flush alt">Word of the Day</p>
<p class="h4 feature-w-big wotd-hw">taro</p><p>a tropical plant that has a root that is cooked and eaten</p>
</div>
<div class="txt-block txt-block--alt with-icons js-eqh-sticky">
<div class="with-icons__content">
<a href="https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/taro" class="a--rev a--b">
<span>About this</span> <i class="fcdo fcdo-angle-right" aria-hidden="true"></i>
</a>
</div>
<div class="with-icons__icons">

</a>

</a>
<div class="pad">
<p class="h2 semi-flush">Blog</p>
<p class="leader semi-flush">

</p>
<p class="meta">

<time>September 26, 2018</time>
</small>
</p>
</div>

</div>

<div class=" 'cols__col' " >
<div class="mod mod--dark mod--border mod--style3">
<a href="https://dictionaryblog.cambridge.org/2018/09/24/new-words-24-september-2018/" target="_blank" class="img">
<p class=box_img___><img alt="binge racing noun" src="/rss/images/binge-racing.jpg" /></p>
</a>
<div class="pad">
<p class="h2 alt semi-flush">New Words</p>
<p class="h4 feature-w semi-flush nw-hw">
<a href="https://dictionaryblog.cambridge.org/2018/09/24/new-words-24-september-2018/" class="a--alt a--rev" target="_blank">binge racing noun</a>
</p>
<p>
<small class="smaller"><time>September 24, 2018</time></small>
</p>
</div>
<a href="https://dictionaryblog.cambridge.org/2018/09/24/new-words-24-september-2018/" target="_blank" class="txt-block txt-block--alt js-eqh-sticky">
